--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> Jim O'Flaherty, Jr. wrote:
> 
> >Ken,
> >
> >Derek wrote:
> >  
> >
> >>Hmm...why not?
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >To your response:
> >  
> >
> >>Yes right, never connect into an input node.
> >>    
> >>
> >
> >I agree with Derek, why not?
> >
> >  
> >
> Thinking back to work I did with back-propagation it seemed to be
the 
> convention in NN work to always distinguish between input, hidden
and 
> output nodes. Now, you can achieve the same results (e.g the LI you 
> descibed) without connections going back to the input 'layer' - you
just 
> perform the inhibition feedback in the first hidden layer. You can 
> actually think of the input nodes as not actually being nodes, just 
> connection points that the real nodes connect to to obtain input
signals.
> 
> My own feelings on this are that it's far more natural to *not* 
> distinguish between input, hidden and outputs nodes. This is how my 
> current NN implementation is arranged. Each node holds a collection
of  
> Connection objects that point to the source of an input signal -
that 
> source can be another node or an element in an input signal array.
By 
> relying on a layer of hidden nodes to substitute for the fact that
input 
> nodes cannot receive connections I think we are effectively
errecting an 
> artifical barrier for the topology search process.
> 
> Ken, I'd be interested in your thoughts on this one while I'm still
at 
> the early stages of development.
> 


I think this discussion is mostly semantics; the "input array" is just
another word for "inputs" in NEAT.  In other words, one might ask you,
"why not have incoming connections to the input array?"  But the point
is, at some level, the inputs are just the inputs.  In NEAT, the
"input nodes" are that level.

My advice is to follow the NEAT conventions unless there is a very
good functional reason not to, because that way it will be easier for
you to ask questions, since then the less your system diverges from
the ones that already exist.  On the other hand, if some design
decision I made was really poor, it is certainly reasonable to try
something different.

ken
